items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: The Groundwater Flood Alert in the Lambourne Valley is no longer in force. Groundwater levels have fallen below the alert threshold following a few drier weeks. Levels are expected to continue falling slowly over the coming weeks. The area will remain sensitive to further rainfall. We will continue to monitor levels and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Ashley Green, Chesham.

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in Chesham such as the Vale Road area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  

We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying lands and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding.   

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.  We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Burn from Southgate and Waterden to Burnham Thorpe
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is still likely today, Monday 29th March, and for the rest of this week. River and groundwater levels remain high and are expected to remain high for the next few weeks. The forecast is for dry conditions today and tomorrow. Take care on riverside footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and levels closely, and will update this message by 10am on Monday 5th April.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom.     
Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom areas are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  
We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of groundwater flooding.   
Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill close to Flamstead.

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  

We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of groundwater flooding.   

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels at the Snailwell Borehole are steady but remain high. Consequently there is an increased risk of groundwater flooding. We expect flooding to affect areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street. There is potential for further rainfall this week, therefore there is a risk that the groundwater levels will remain high over the next few weeks. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message is updated weekly due to the slow reaction and will be updated Wednesday 31 March, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message: The Nailbourne & Little Stour have been flowing since mid-January. Levels peaked in February and are now slowly in recession. However, some flooding of low-lying land, gardens and roads is still occurring at various locations including North Elham, Barham, Patrixbourne, Bridge and Littlebourne. Some roads remain closed at fording points. The internal flooding of residential properties is not expected. The Littlebourne Flood Relief Channel is in operation and temporary defences operate in Barham. Please avoid driving in floodwater as bow waves from vehicles may cause property flooding. Environment Agency operatives are ensuring the free flow of water. We are monitoring the situation and co-ordinating efforts with local authorities and community leaders. Levels are gradually reducing but this alert will remain in force until more roads are opened to traffic. This message will be updated by Friday 2 April or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Marham and Setchey Bridge river gauges. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible. We expect flooding to affect the River Nar from Litcham to South Lynn. No rainfall is forecast over the next few days, however we expect the river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Tuesday 30 March, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm in the Great Shefford area are slowly falling due to limited rainfall over the last few weeks. Groundwater levels are still above normal for this time of year, and are still high and close to a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater if we receive heavy rainfall. 

We expect levels to remain high, but continue to fall slowly over the next week. Water levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and could start to rise again in response to rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message Tuesday (30/03/2021), or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Mint Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Staveley, Ings, Burneside, Kendal, Garnett Bridge, Stainton, Sedgwick, Holme, Beetham and Milnthorpe areas. High river levels are possible on the Rivers Kent, Gowan, Sprint, Mint, Stock Beck, Stainton Beck, Peasey Beck, Farleton Beck, River Bela, Holme Beck and their tributaries.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours but gradually clearing.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow 30/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Derwent Water lake level remains high as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Seatoller, Stonethwaite, Rosthwaite, Grange-in-Borrowdale and Derwent Water shoreline areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Watendlath Beck, Derwent Water and their tributaries.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours but gradually clearing.  We expect lake levels to remain high into tomorrow 30/03/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow 30/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:

High river and lake levels are possible on Great Langdale Beck, River Brathay, River Rothay, Trout Beck, Mill Beck, Cunsey Beck, Windermere Lake, Rusland Pool, River Eea, River Winster and their tributaries.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours but gradually clearing.  We expect lake levels to remain high into tomorrow 30/03/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow 30/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message: River levels are now falling again and are expected to continue to do so through today, Monday 29th March. No further significant rainfall is expected over the next few days.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater remains high.  Over the last 7 days, there has been a slight increase in level in Appleshaw and Hatherden, as groundwater responded to rain which was recorded between 10th and 13th March. In Kimpton, the level continues to fall. From today (Wednesday 24/03/21) until next week, small amounts of rain are forecast, with heavy showers expected on Friday (26/03/21). In Hatherden and Appleshaw, groundwater has not yet lowered for a period of several successive days.  Rain this week could therefore cause levels to rise (perhaps by another 10 cm or so). Whilst it is unlikely that rain this week will cause impacts, groundwater is only marginally below a level where historically, a small  number of cellars have been affected in Hatherden and Appleshaw. We would therefore like communities to remain prepared, just over the next few weeks. We will update this message by 12:00 on Wednesday 31st March 2021.

River levels are high but steady at Pooley Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Bampton, Patterdale, Glenridding, Dockray, Pooley Bridge, Dacre, Eamont Bridge and Penrith areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Lowther, Haweswater Beck, Goldrill Beck, Grisedale Beck, Glenridding Beck, Aira Beck, Ullswater, River Eamont, Dacre Beck, Thacka Beck and their tributaries.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours but gradually clearing.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow 30/03/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow 30/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Gilling Beck, Skeeby Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Swale is no longer in force.  River levels have fallen below levels of concern and no further flooding is currently expected.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

River and lake levels remain high at the Lodore gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site     
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours but gradually clearing.  We expect water levels to remain high into tomorrow 30/03/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow 30/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The Flood Alert for the Lower Swale remains in force as river levels remain high at both Maunby, and Crakehill, in response to recent heavy rain. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: The flood warning for the River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park remains in force due to rising river levels following recent heavy rainfall. The river level at Westwick Weir is currently 1.61m and is forecast to rise slowly, peaking at approximately 1.7m this afternoon, Monday 29th March. Consequently, flooding is expected today in the Roecliffe Caravan Park area. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Appleby river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Ravenstonedale, Kirkby Stephen, Brough, Warcop, Great Asby, Great Ormside, Appleby-in-Westmorland, Bolton, Crosby Ravensworth and Morland areas. High river levels are possible on the River Eden, Scandal Beck, Swindale Beck, Crooks Beck, Asby Beck, River Lyvennet, Morland Beck and their tributaries.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours but gradually clearing.  We expect river levels to begin falling at around 09:00 on 29/03/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow 30/03/2021 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels are rising at the South Street Footbridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday and overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Buttermere, Lorton Valley, Cockermouth, Branthwaite, Bridgefoot, Camerton, Barepot and Workington areas. High river levels are possible on the River Cocker, Whit Beck, River Derwent, River Marron, Lostrigg Beck and their tributaries. Early morning rain will clear away before lunchtime today, 29/03/2021. River levels will remain high until mid-afternoon. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are clearing debris screens. Please avoid contact with floodwater and avoid low-lying roads and footpaths near rivers. This message will be updated this afternoon, 29/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the Upper River Wharfe is no longer in force.  River levels have fallen below levels of concern and no further flooding is currently expected.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high astronomical tides today, Monday 29th March, between 18:30 and 20:00.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels are now falling again and are expected to continue to do so through today, Monday 29th March. No further significant rainfall is expected over the next few days.  Water in washlands around Skipton and Cononley will gradually drain as the River Aire falls.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The Flood Alert for the Tidal River Ouse remains in force, due to rising river levels as a result of recent heavy rainfall. The River Ouse in York is currently 2.2m and is expected to continue to rise steadily throughout today, Monday 29th March, reaching approximately 3m in the early hours of tomorrow morning, Tuesday 30th March. The current river level at Naburn is 1.8m and is also expected to continue to rise throughout today. Consequently, flooding of low lying footpaths, roads and farmland is possible. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Tuesday morning and evening, and Wednesday morning. High water at Ilfracombe is at 8am on Tuesday morning and at 8:30pm on Tuesday evening.  On Wednesday, high water at Ilfracombe is at 8:45am. Times of high water will vary along the coast.  There may be minor overtopping of sea defences at exposed locations.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 5.16mAOD on Tuesday morning and 5.06mAOD on Tuesday evening.
River levels are now falling again and are expected to continue to do so through today, Monday 29th March. No further significant rainfall is expected over the next few days.

The Flood Alert for the Upper Ure remains in force. River levels in the Upper Ure catchment remain high due to recent heavy rainfall. The River Ure at Kilgram is currently at 3.3m and rising, but is expected to peak within the next few hours and should begin to fall later this morning, Monday 29th March. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High still water level is expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 10:30 and 14:30 today, 29/03/21. Flooding to properties/roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Fleetwood Docks and Marina, Fleetwood Marsh Nature Park, Barnaby's Sands, Burn Naze, Sower Carr, Hambleton, Stannah, Trunnah, Thornton, Skippool and Little Eccleston.   
The next high tide at 01:00 on 30/03/2021 is also expected to exceed the Flood Alert threshold. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated  this afternoon, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

A Flood Alert remains in place today as large and powerful waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Consequently, flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible between 10:45 and 14:45 Monday, 29/03/21.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Mossband Hall, Eden estuary, Burgh Marsh, Port Carlisle, Bowness-on-Solway, Wampool estuary, Waver estuary, Skinburness Marsh, Skinburness and Silloth.    

We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline. The high tide tomorrow tonight may also cross the Flood Alert threshold and will be updated later this afternoon, Monday 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

It is forecast that the high tide tonight at 01:00 on the 30/03/21 will also reach the Flood Alert criteria. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Roosebeck, South Ulverston, Canal Foot, Crake estuary, Rusland Valley, Leven estuary, Eea estuary, Flookburgh, East Plain Farm, Grange-over-Sands, Meathop, Kent estuary, Milnthorpe, B5282 coast road, Sandside and Arnside.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline. The high tide this evening will also cross the Flood Alert threshold and will be updated later today, Monday 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the first forecast high water is 07:30 on 29/03/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.36 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 4 in a south south west direction. The time and date of the second forecast high water is 20:00 on 29/03/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.37 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 3 in a south south west direction. There is a possibility of flooding for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham, and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehamption Park, including Pill and Shirehampton.

Our operation teams are closing flood gates in the Pill and Shirehampton area. 
Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

The high tide is expected to be higher than usual as a result of high tides. Consequently flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is possible from 13:00 today, 29/03/21. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry between 13:15 and 14:00, with a peak of 6.45m, Eastford Road between 13:30 and 14:15, with a peak of 6.61m, and Arpley Bridge between 13:45 and 14:45, with a peak of 6.66m, It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. Based on current forecast, the subsequent 2 high tides are also forecast to reach the flood alert threshold tomorrow 30/03/21. We will issue further alerts and update this message as necessary

items.description: River Greta at Keswick, Keswick Campsite, Rugby Club and Quinta
items.message:

Including Greta Park Rugby Football Ground, Keswick Campsite, Keswick School Sports Field, Keswick Show Field and Playing Field areas   
We expect river levels to remain high until later today 29/03/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 30/03/21, or as the situation changes.

Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated  this afternoon, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

High still water level is expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 10:30 and 14:30 today, 29/03/21. Flooding to properties/roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at White Lund, Heysham Moss, south Heysham, Potts Corner, Sunderland Point, Thurnham, Cockersands Abbey, Bank Houses, Cockerham, Braides, Cockerham Moss and surrounding areas.   
The next high tide at 01:00 on 30/03/2021 is also expected to exceed the Flood Alert threshold. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated  this afternoon, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.
